customer_addr:
15412 Front Beach Road
Panama City Beach, FL 32413

citations.narrative:
***The main sea lion stadium pool and back holding pools are still in disrepair throughout the area. The shade structure
over the public seating area is deteriorating. The staff reports that pieces of the structure fall and, “get wind-blown” into
the sea lion and seal main show pool. There is still evidence of rust coming through the wall and running down into the
water of the main show pool which can impact water quality. The back wall along the stage is in disrepair with sections of
wood broken and paint chipping. Areas of concrete on the stage side of the pool along the back is broken and actively
breaking off creating sharp points, where seals are hauling out of the water. Lastly, there are still large sections where
paint is actively chipping off the walls along the water line in the seal holding pools which can impact the water quality or
become an ingestion hazard to the seals.
*** There is cracked and broken concrete all around the perimeter of the far west dolphin pool. These areas of concrete
are breaking off and when touched by the inspector, the powder under broken areas is coming up and loose. This can be
a hazard as the concrete powder can be wind blown into the pool impacting water quality for the animals.
Facilities where animals are housed must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.

While shade has been provided over dolphin west pool, there is still no shade provided over the far side of dolphin east
pool where dry guest interactions are done, or the over the main show stage where the dolphins station for food during
training sessions with the trainers or during public guest interactions after shows. The lack of shade in these key areas
makes it necessary for the dolphins to bring their heads up out of the water and feed facing the sunlight during the show
and during guest interaction programs. Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable for the animals and excessive exposure to
sunlight has been linked to the development of eye abnormalities in captive marine mammals.
The facility must provide the animals protection from direct sunlight for their health and wellbeing.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
ANDREA D AMBROSIO, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.101(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
***The main sea lion stadium pool and back holding pools are still in disrepair throughout the area. The shade structure 
over the public seating area is deteriorating. The staff reports that pieces of the structure fall and, “get wind-blown” into 
the sea lion and seal main show pool. There is still evidence of rust coming through the wall and running down into the 
water of the main show pool which can impact water quality. The back wall along the stage is in disrepair with sections of 
wood broken and paint chipping. Areas of concrete on the stage side of the pool along the back is broken and actively 
breaking off creating sharp points, where seals are hauling out of the water. Lastly, there are still large sections where 
paint is actively chipping off the walls along the water line in the seal holding pools which can impact the water quality or 
become an ingestion hazard to the seals. 
 
*** There is cracked and broken concrete all around the perimeter of the far west dolphin pool. These areas of concrete 
are breaking off and when touched by the inspector, the powder under broken areas is coming up and loose. This can be 
a hazard as the concrete powder can be wind blown into the pool impacting water quality for the animals.  
 
Facilities where animals are housed must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
3.103(b)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
While shade has been provided over dolphin west pool, there is still no shade provided over the far side of dolphin east 
pool where dry guest interactions are done, or the over the main show stage where the dolphins station for food during 
training sessions with the trainers or during public guest interactions after shows. The lack of shade in these key areas 
makes it necessary for the dolphins to bring their heads up out of the water and feed facing the sunlight during the show 
and during guest interaction programs. Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable for the animals and excessive exposure to 
sunlight has been linked to the development of eye abnormalities in captive marine mammals.  
 
The facility must provide the animals protection from direct sunlight for their health and wellbeing.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ANDREA D AMBROSIO, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
